objectives: Connect words and sentences using conjunctions
Understand and use coordinating conjunctions (and, but, or, so)
Understand and use subordinating conjunctions (because, although, when, if)
Combine simple sentences to make longer, more meaningful ones

sections.text: Conjunctions are like small joining words. They connect words, groups of words (phrases), or whole sentences. They help us to make our sentences longer and show how ideas are linked. Without conjunctions, our sentences would be very short and choppy, like 'I went. I saw. I ate.' Conjunctions make our language smoother and clearer. They are like glue for words and sentences.

examples.label: Connecting words
examples.value: I like rice and dal.

examples.label: Connecting phrases
examples.value: He plays in the field or near the well.

examples.label: Connecting sentences
examples.value: It was raining, but we went to school.

examples.label: Showing reason
examples.value: I study hard because I want to succeed.

examples.label: Joining two actions
examples.value: She cleaned the house and cooked food.

examples.label: Joining two people
examples.value: Ram and Sita went to the market.

examples.label: Joining two places
examples.value: They travelled to the village or to the city.

examples.label: Joining two ideas
examples.value: The dog is small but it is very strong.

examples.label: Showing result
examples.value: I was hungry, so I ate a mango.

examples.label: Showing condition
examples.value: If it rains, we will stay home.

examples.label: Showing time
examples.value: When the sun sets, we go home.

examples.label: Showing contrast
examples.value: Although he was tired, he worked in the field.

examples.label: Connecting two qualities
examples.value: The old man is wise and kind.

examples.label: Connecting two choices
examples.value: Do you want tea or coffee?

examples.label: Connecting two facts
examples.value: The well is deep and it has fresh water.

examples.label: Connecting animals
examples.value: The farmer has a cow and a goat.

examples.label: Connecting choices of place
examples.value: We can rest under the tree or by the river.

examples.label: Connecting contrasting facts
examples.value: The path was long, but it was not difficult.

examples.label: Connecting reason and action
examples.value: We light a lamp because it is dark.

examples.label: Connecting two results
examples.value: He felt tired, so he went to sleep.

usage_examples: Conjunctions help join ideas.
They make sentences longer.
We use them every day.
They make our speech smooth.
Learning them helps in writing.

sections.text: 'And' is used to add information or to join two similar ideas, words, or sentences. It shows that two things go together or happen one after another. It means 'also' or 'in addition to'.

examples.label: Joining two words (nouns)
examples.value: I like rice and dal.

examples.label: Joining two words (verbs)
examples.value: He ran and jumped.

examples.label: Joining two words (adjectives)
examples.value: The weather is hot and humid.

examples.label: Joining two simple sentences
examples.value: She went to the market, and she bought vegetables.

examples.label: Joining actions that happen together
examples.value: The children laughed and played.

examples.label: Joining items in a list
examples.value: We need milk, sugar, and tea leaves.

examples.label: Adding more information about a person
examples.value: My father is a farmer, and he works very hard.

examples.label: Connecting two similar events
examples.value: The sun rose, and the birds started chirping.

examples.label: Linking two related ideas
examples.value: He finished his work, and then he went home.

examples.label: Combining two short sentences
examples.value: The buffalo eats grass, and it gives milk.

examples.label: Linking two activities
examples.value: In the evening, I read books and listen to stories.

examples.label: Adding a detail
examples.value: The river is wide, and it flows quickly.

examples.label: Connecting two qualities
examples.value: The old temple is beautiful and peaceful.

examples.label: Linking two tasks
examples.value: Clean your room and wash your hands before eating.

examples.label: Joining a list of village animals
examples.value: We have cows, goats, and chickens on our farm.

examples.label: Joining two more qualities
examples.value: He is tall and strong.

examples.label: Joining two actions of one person
examples.value: The woman fetches water and washes clothes.

examples.label: Joining two descriptions
examples.value: The village is small, and the people are friendly.

usage_examples: He eats bread and eggs.
I went to school and learned new things.
The road is long and dusty.
We play and study every day.
My mother cooked and served food.

sections.text: 'But' is used to show a difference or a contrast between two ideas. It means 'however' or 'on the other hand'. It often connects two ideas that are opposite or unexpected.

examples.label: Opposite ideas
examples.value: It's raining, but we will go to school.

examples.label: Showing contrast
examples.value: He is small, but he is strong.

examples.label: Unexpected result
examples.value: She studied hard, but she did not pass.

examples.label: Contrasting two qualities
examples.value: The food looks good, but it does not taste good.

examples.label: Contrasting two actions
examples.value: I wanted to go, but I could not.

examples.label: Contrasting effort and result
examples.value: He tried his best, but he failed.

examples.label: Contrasting situation and action
examples.value: The well is deep, but it has little water now.

examples.label: Contrasting desire and reality
examples.value: I like to play, but I have homework to do.

examples.label: Contrasting qualities
examples.value: The old bull is slow, but it is very powerful.

examples.label: Contrasting appearance and truth
examples.value: He looks rich, but he lives simply.

examples.label: Contrasting plan and obstacle
examples.value: We planned to go to the river, but the path was blocked.

examples.label: Contrasting feeling and action
examples.value: I am tired, but I must finish this work.

examples.label: Contrasting size and strength
examples.value: The young tree is thin, but its roots are strong.

examples.label: Contrasting situation and persistence
examples.value: It was dark, but they continued their journey.

examples.label: Contrasting preference and reality
examples.value: I like the city, but I live in the village.

examples.label: Contrasting age and activity
examples.value: My grandfather is old, but he still works in the field.

examples.label: Contrasting qualities of water
examples.value: The water is cool, but it is not clean.

examples.label: Contrasting character
examples.value: He is poor, but he is honest.

examples.label: Contrasting action and result
examples.value: I called his name, but he did not hear me.

usage_examples: The boy is shy, but he is clever.
It was hot, but we enjoyed the game.
She wanted to speak, but she felt nervous.
The road is rough, but it leads to a beautiful place.
I like sweets, but I don't eat them often.

sections.text: 'Or' is used to show a choice between two or more things or ideas. It means 'either this or that'.

examples.label: Giving a choice
examples.value: Do you want tea or coffee?

examples.label: Choice of actions
examples.value: You can play inside or outside.

examples.label: Choice of things
examples.value: Will you eat rice or roti?

examples.label: Asking about options
examples.value: Should we walk or take the bus?

examples.label: Suggesting alternatives
examples.value: We can go to the market or to the temple.

examples.label: Choice of time
examples.value: Will you come today or tomorrow?

examples.label: Choice of person
examples.value: Is it Ram or Shyam who won the race?

examples.label: Choice of method
examples.value: We can dig a new well or clean the old one.

examples.label: Offering two possibilities
examples.value: You can study now or help me with the chores later.

examples.label: Asking about preference
examples.value: Do you prefer a small village or a big city?

examples.label: Choice of place
examples.value: Let's meet at the school or near the banyan tree.

examples.label: Asking about different types
examples.value: Do you want red chilies or green chilies?

examples.label: Presenting two options for an action
examples.value: Should I bring water or some food for the journey?

examples.label: Providing alternatives for a situation
examples.value: We can wait for him or go without him.

examples.label: Choice for transportation
examples.value: Will you go by foot or by bicycle?

examples.label: A choice of truth
examples.value: Is the story true or false?

examples.label: Presenting a consequence
examples.value: You must work hard, or you will not succeed.

examples.label: Choice of crops
examples.value: We can plant maize or wheat this season.

usage_examples: Do you want to play or read?
Is the cow black or white?
We can go to the river or the pond.
Finish your work, or you will be late.
Should I wear a shirt or a kurta?

sections.text: 'So' is used to show the result or consequence of something. It means 'as a result' or 'therefore'. The second part of the sentence happens because of the first part.

examples.label: Showing result
examples.value: I was hungry, so I ate a mango.

examples.label: Consequence of action
examples.value: It was hot, so I drank water.

examples.label: Result of a situation
examples.value: He was sick, so he went to the doctor.

examples.label: Reason and outcome
examples.value: The bus was late, so I missed school.

examples.label: Cause leading to effect
examples.value: It rained heavily, so the fields are wet.

examples.label: Problem and solution
examples.value: I lost my pen, so I borrowed one from my friend.

examples.label: Situation and decision
examples.value: The crops are ready, so farmers are harvesting.

examples.label: Effort and outcome
examples.value: She studied hard, so she passed the exam.

examples.label: Fact and conclusion
examples.value: The sun is setting, so it will be dark soon.

examples.label: Condition and response
examples.value: I felt tired, so I rested under the tree.

examples.label: Observation and action
examples.value: The baby was crying, so his mother picked him up.

examples.label: Need and action
examples.value: We needed fresh water, so we cleaned the well.

examples.label: Opportunity and action
examples.value: The market was closed, so we bought vegetables from a small shop.

examples.label: Information and action
examples.value: He knew the way, so he led the group.

examples.label: Problem and consequence
examples.value: The road was slippery, so the bicycle fell.

examples.label: Need and action 2
examples.value: The well was dry, so we walked to the river.

examples.label: Feeling and action
examples.value: He was feeling unwell, so he rested at home.

examples.label: Action and result for a group
examples.value: The teacher explained the lesson again, so the students understood it better.

usage_examples: It was cold, so I wore a sweater.
She worked hard, so she earned money.
My buffalo was sick, so I called the vet.
The movie was boring, so I slept.
He finished his chores, so he went to play.

sections.text: Coordinating conjunctions (and, but, or, so) connect words, phrases, or sentences that are of equal importance. When you join two full sentences (which can stand alone) with a coordinating conjunction, put a comma before the conjunction. If you are joining only words or phrases, you usually do not need a comma.

examples.label: Two full sentences (comma needed)
examples.value: I woke up early, and I went for a walk.

examples.label: Two full sentences (comma needed)
examples.value: She likes to sing, but she does not like to dance.

examples.label: Two full sentences (comma needed)
examples.value: You can leave now, or you can wait for them.

examples.label: Two full sentences (comma needed)
examples.value: The lights went out, so we lit a lamp.

examples.label: Two words (no comma)
examples.value: He brought bread and eggs.

examples.label: Two phrases (no comma)
examples.value: She studies in the morning or in the evening.

examples.label: No comma when connecting two verbs with same subject
examples.value: He ran fast and jumped high.

examples.label: Comma before 'and' joining two independent clauses
examples.value: The farmer watered the plants, and the crops grew well.

examples.label: Comma before 'but' joining two independent clauses
examples.value: The sky was cloudy, but it did not rain.

examples.label: Comma before 'or' joining two independent clauses
examples.value: We can build a new house, or we can repair the old one.

examples.label: Comma before 'so' joining two independent clauses
examples.value: The children were tired, so they went to sleep.

examples.label: No comma when connecting two nouns as a compound subject
examples.value: My brother and sister are playing outside.

examples.label: No comma when connecting two adjective phrases
examples.value: The village is peaceful and full of green trees.

examples.label: Comma with 'and' for lists of three or more
examples.value: She bought rice, dal, and vegetables.

examples.label: No comma when connecting two ideas directly
examples.value: He likes to read and write stories.

examples.label: More with comma: 'but'
examples.value: He ran fast, but he missed the bus.

examples.label: More without comma: 'and'
examples.value: The flowers are red and yellow.

examples.label: More with comma: 'so'
examples.value: The night was dark, so he took a torch with him.

usage_examples: Remember the comma rule for full sentences.
Do not put a comma if you join only two words.
And and or are simple joiners.
But and so show more meaning.
Practice helps you use them right.

table.title: Coordinating Conjunctions: Comma Rule
rows: He runs fast or swims well.
I like rice, roti, and curry.

sections.text: 'Because' is used to give a reason or cause for something. It answers the question 'Why?'. The part of the sentence with 'because' tells us the reason, and this part cannot stand alone as a full sentence. It needs the main part of the sentence to make sense.

examples.label: Reason for action
examples.value: I study hard because I want to succeed.

examples.label: Reason for feeling
examples.value: She is happy because she passed the exam.

examples.label: Reason for a situation
examples.value: We stayed home because it was raining heavily.

examples.label: Reason for consequence
examples.value: He missed the bus because he woke up late.

examples.label: Why something happened
examples.value: The ground is wet because it rained all night.

examples.label: Reason for choice
examples.value: I drink water because I am thirsty.

examples.label: Reason for effort
examples.value: Farmers work hard because they want good crops.

examples.label: Reason for a decision
examples.value: We went to the pond because the well was dry.

examples.label: Explaining behavior
examples.value: The dog barked because it saw a stranger.

examples.label: Reason for being late
examples.value: He was late to school because his bicycle had a flat tire.

examples.label: Explaining a state
examples.value: She felt sad because her pet goat was ill.

examples.label: Reason for enjoyment
examples.value: The children love the festival because there are many games.

examples.label: Explaining a condition
examples.value: The plants died because there was no water for many days.

examples.label: Why something is preferred
examples.value: I like this village because it is peaceful and green.

examples.label: Reason for change
examples.value: He learned quickly because he practiced daily.

examples.label: Cause of an event
examples.value: The river flooded because of the continuous heavy rain.

examples.label: Reason for emotion
examples.value: The child is crying because he is hungry.

examples.label: Reason for a specific action
examples.value: We cover the food because we want to keep flies away.

examples.label: Reason for social status
examples.value: He is respected because he is wise and fair.

usage_examples: I eat healthy food because I want to be strong.
She cried because she lost her toy.
We went early because we wanted to get good seats.
The road was muddy because of the rain.
He felt cold because he forgot his sweater.

sections.text: 'Although' is used to show a contrast or something that is surprising or unexpected compared to the main idea. It means 'even though' or 'in spite of the fact that'. The part with 'although' is a dependent idea.

examples.label: Contrast of ideas
examples.value: Although he was tired, he finished his homework.

examples.label: Unexpected situation
examples.value: Although it was hot, she wore a long dress.

examples.label: Contrasting qualities
examples.value: Although he is rich, he lives a simple life in the village.

examples.label: Contrasting actions
examples.value: Although she was scared, she walked alone at night.

examples.label: Unexpected result
examples.value: Although they practiced a lot, they did not win the game.

examples.label: Contrasting appearance and reality
examples.value: Although the book looks old, it has many new ideas.

examples.label: Contrasting feelings and actions
examples.value: Although he was angry, he stayed calm and listened.

examples.label: Surprising situation
examples.value: Although it was a holiday, the shops were open in the market.

examples.label: Contrasting effort and outcome
examples.value: Although he tried his best, he could not lift the heavy stone.

examples.label: Contrasting condition and choice
examples.value: Although the road was rough, we enjoyed the journey on the bullock cart.

examples.label: Contrasting ability and action
examples.value: Although she can sing well, she is shy to sing in front of others.

examples.label: Unexpected persistence
examples.value: Although the sun was very hot, the farmers continued their work in the field.

examples.label: Contrasting size and function
examples.value: Although the hut is small, it is very comfortable inside.

examples.label: Unexpected kindness
examples.value: Although he was a stranger, he helped the old woman in need.

examples.label: Contrasting age and wisdom
examples.value: Although she is young, she speaks with much wisdom.

examples.label: Unexpected success
examples.value: Although he didn't study much, he passed the exam well.

examples.label: Unexpected safety
examples.value: Although the storm was strong, our hut was safe.

examples.label: Unexpected action despite condition
examples.value: He went to work in the field, although he felt sick.

examples.label: Unexpected effort
examples.value: Although the river is far, we go there for fresh fish.

usage_examples: Although it rained, we went for a walk.
She ate the food, although she was not hungry.
Although he is old, he is still strong.
We went to the river, although the water was cold.
Although the village is small, it has a good school.

sections.text: 'When' is used to show the time at which something happens. It tells us that one action takes place at the same time as, or immediately after, another action. It can be used for past, present, or future events.

examples.label: At the same time (past)
examples.value: When I was young, I played a lot.

examples.label: One after another (past)
examples.value: When the bell rang, students went home.

examples.label: At the same time (present)
examples.value: When the sun shines, the plants grow.

examples.label: Future event (present simple in 'when' clause)
examples.value: When he comes, we will eat dinner.

examples.label: Time of an action
examples.value: When the rain falls, the ground gets wet.

examples.label: Time of a discovery
examples.value: I found my keys when I cleaned my room.

examples.label: Simultaneous actions
examples.value: When my mother cooks, I help her chop vegetables.

examples.label: Time of a feeling
examples.value: She feels happy when she sees her family.

examples.label: Time of a routine
examples.value: When it is morning, we wake up and pray.

examples.label: Time of arrival
examples.value: When the bus arrived, many people got on it.

examples.label: Time of natural event
examples.value: When the monsoon season starts, the river fills up.

examples.label: Time of learning
examples.value: I learn many new things when I read books.

examples.label: Past habit
examples.value: When we were children, we used to play near the banyan tree.

examples.label: Time of a specific event
examples.value: When the full moon rises, the village looks very bright.

examples.label: Indicating specific moment
examples.value: He felt a pain when he lifted the heavy bag of grains.

examples.label: Time of an action related to farming
examples.value: When the crops are ripe, farmers begin to harvest them.

examples.label: Showing hospitality
examples.value: When the guests arrive, we offer them water.

examples.label: Time for a specific feeling
examples.value: I feel peaceful when I sit near the temple.

examples.label: Seasonal action
examples.value: When winter comes, we wear warm clothes.

usage_examples: When I eat, I feel strong.
When he arrived, we were sleeping.
When the teacher speaks, we listen.
When the power goes, we use a lamp.
When the festival comes, everyone is happy.

sections.text: 'If' is used to show a condition. It tells us that something will happen only if a certain condition is met. It means 'on the condition that'. The part with 'if' is the condition, and the other part is the result.

examples.label: Condition and result
examples.value: If it rains, we will stay home.

examples.label: Condition for success
examples.value: If you study hard, you will pass the exam.

examples.label: Condition for action
examples.value: If you need help, please ask me.

examples.label: Possible condition
examples.value: If he comes, tell him I am waiting.

examples.label: Condition for outcome
examples.value: If you work in the field, you will get tired.

examples.label: Condition for health
examples.value: If you drink clean water, you will not get sick.

examples.label: Condition for a gift
examples.value: If you finish your chores, I will give you a sweet.

examples.label: Condition for opportunity
examples.value: If the weather is good, we will go to the river.

examples.label: Condition for understanding
examples.value: If you listen carefully, you will understand the lesson.

examples.label: Condition for safety
examples.value: If you walk on this path, be careful of snakes.

examples.label: Condition for planting
examples.value: If the soil is dry, we must water the plants first.

examples.label: Condition for growth
examples.value: If there is enough sunlight, the crops will grow tall.

examples.label: Condition for problem solving
examples.value: If we work together, we can clean the whole village pond.

examples.label: Condition for seeking help
examples.value: If you are lost, ask an elder for directions.

examples.label: Condition for good result
examples.value: If you practice daily, your English speaking will improve fast.

examples.label: Condition for good harvest
examples.value: If the monsoon is good, farmers will have a good harvest.

examples.label: Condition for plant life
examples.value: If you plant a seed, it will grow into a plant.

examples.label: Condition with a negative consequence
examples.value: If the bus does not come, we will have to walk.

examples.label: Suggesting a conditional action
examples.value: If you are tired, you should rest for some time.

usage_examples: If you are hungry, eat food.
If the well is dry, use water from the river.
If you go to the market, buy some vegetables.
If he calls, tell him I am busy.
If you study, you will learn.

subtopics.title: Conjunction Usage Rules and Sentence Combining

sections.text: Subordinating conjunctions (like because, although, when, if) join a dependent sentence part to a main sentence part. The dependent part cannot stand alone. When the dependent part comes before the main part, we usually use a comma after it. When the main part comes first, usually no comma is needed. We combine sentences to make our writing flow better and to show clear relationships between ideas.

examples.label: Dependent clause first (comma needed)
examples.value: Because it was cold, I wore a jacket.

examples.label: Dependent clause first (comma needed)
examples.value: Although she was tired, she continued to work.

examples.label: Dependent clause first (comma needed)
examples.value: When the sun set, we went inside.

examples.label: Dependent clause first (comma needed)
examples.value: If you work hard, you will succeed.

examples.label: Main clause first (no comma)
examples.value: I wore a jacket because it was cold.

examples.label: Main clause first (no comma)
examples.value: She continued to work although she was tired.

examples.label: Main clause first (no comma)
examples.value: We went inside when the sun set.

examples.label: Main clause first (no comma)
examples.value: You will succeed if you work hard.

examples.label: Combining sentences: separate to combined
examples.value: The boy was hungry. He ate all the bread. -> The boy ate all the bread because he was hungry.

examples.label: Combining sentences: separate to combined
examples.value: She has little money. She buys things for everyone. -> Although she has little money, she buys things for everyone.

examples.label: Combining sentences: separate to combined
examples.value: The rain stopped. We went out to play. -> When the rain stopped, we went out to play.

examples.label: Combining sentences: separate to combined
examples.value: You listen carefully. You will understand. -> If you listen carefully, you will understand.

examples.label: Combining two ideas with 'and'
examples.value: My brother plays football. My sister plays kabaddi. -> My brother plays football and my sister plays kabaddi.

examples.label: Combining two contrasting ideas with 'but'
examples.value: The mango is sweet. It is small. -> The mango is sweet, but it is small.

examples.label: Combining two options with 'or'
examples.value: We can eat now. We can eat later. -> We can eat now or we can eat later.

examples.label: Combining cause and effect with 'so'
examples.value: He felt sleepy. He went to bed. -> He felt sleepy, so he went to bed.

examples.label: More combining: because
examples.value: The child was happy. He got a new toy. -> The child was happy because he got a new toy.

examples.label: More combining: although
examples.value: The test was difficult. I passed it. -> Although the test was difficult, I passed it.

examples.label: More combining: but
examples.value: The sun is hot. The wind is cool. -> The sun is hot, but the wind is cool.

examples.label: More combining: if
examples.value: We must start now. We will be late. -> If we don't start now, we will be late.

usage_examples: Think about the link between your ideas.
Choose the right conjunction for that link.
Remember the comma rule for subordinating conjunctions.
Practice combining short sentences.
This makes your writing much better.

table.title: Subordinating Conjunctions: Comma Rule
rows: Because it's hot, I'll drink water.
I'll drink water because it's hot.
